content.text: A skateboarder is initially at rest at point A. The skateboarder then travels through point B and comes to rest at point C
Describe the transfer of energy as the skateboarder travels from A to B to C along the concrete track
B is at ground level and C is at \(2.8 \text{m}\) above ground level. The mass of the skateboarder is \(65 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the work done on the skateboarder as she travels from B to C
work done =   .........
The skateboarder falls off the skateboard at B. She hits the track and comes to rest after a few milliseconds
State the equation that defines the force \(F\) with which the skateboarder hits the track. State the meaning of any symbols you use
Fig. 3.1 shows a side view of part of a concrete track at a skateboard park
State the main method of thermal energy transfer throughout the air in the room
Explain how the heater warms all the air in the room
Show that the current in the heater is approximately 8.7A
The plug connecting the heater to the mains supply is fitted with a fuse
Fuse ratings of 3A, 5A, 10A and 13A are available
State which fuse is used. Explain your answer
fuse
explanation
The power of the heater is \(2.0 \text{kW}\) when it is connected to the mains supply with an e.m.f. of \(230 \text{V}\)

Calculate the frequency of the light
The ray of light is monochromatic red light with a wavelength of \(680 \text{nm}\) in air

soap film

A power station generates electricity at 25 000 V. A transformer steps up the voltage to 300 000 V. The primary coil of the step-up transformer has 450 turns

Suggest how the nucleus of a stable isotope of strontium differs from a nucleus of strontium-90. Explain your answer
suggestion
explanation
Complete the nuclide equation for the decay of strontium-90 to yttrium
Explain why scientists limit the amount of time they are exposed to radioactive strontium
Yttrium is also unstable. A scientist places a sample of yttrium near a radiation detector
Table 9.1 shows the count rate recorded by the detector as the sample decays

Strontium-90 ( \(^{90}_{38}\mathrm{Sr})\) is a radioactive isotope that contains 38 protons and 52 neutrons. Strontium-90 decays to form an isotope of yttrium (Y) by emitting beta (\(\beta\)) particles
Describe the composition of Jupiter and the Earth
Jupiter
the Earth
Define gravitational field strength
State one factor which causes the difference between the gravitational field strength at the surface of Jupiter and the gravitational field strength at the surface of the Earth
The gravitational field strength at the surface of the Earth is approximately \(9.8 \text{N / kg}\). The gravitational field strength at the surface of Jupiter is approximately \(23 \text{N / kg}\)
State and explain the difference between the orbital speed of Jupiter and the orbital speed of the Earth
statement
explanation
Jupiter and the Earth are planets in our Solar System
